results.title: Education: where do we go from here?
results.creator_credit: Ron Rowe and Rowe and Co Communications
results.brief_description: A wide variety of education academics, administrators politicians and teacher-union leaders talk about the increasing irrelevance of education systems. Those interviewed include Barry Jones, Dr. Lawrie Shears, Dr. Ken Mckinnon and Professor Headley Beare.

results.title: Becoming a student again
results.creator_credit: John Garrity and Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology
results.brief_description: A motivational program aimed at putting mature-age students at ease with the idea of returning to study at TAFE colleges. Indicates the process of enrolment, the expectations of students and the TAFE colleges, and the problems likely to be encountered at home by mature age students.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Garrity and Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology

results.title: Democratic curriculum
results.creator_credit: David Woodgate, Dean Ashden and Focus Films
results.brief_description: Provides an overview of the direction of education in Australia today as it comes to terms with changing society. Looks at schools in Victoria and South Australia and presents the views of educators, parents and children about the best ways educators can meet the needs of individual students. Considers goal based assessment, non sexist curricula and curricula supporting the needs of girls who have not received equal classroom opportunities. Outlines the underlaying principles behind the new ‘democratic curriculum’.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Woodgate, Dean Ashden and Focus Films

results.title: Making it relevant
results.creator_credit: James Mann and Victoria. Dept. of Education and Early Childhood Development
results.brief_description: Looks at the need to make changes in the curriculum in order to cater for the many students now staying at schools who are perhaps not interested in further education. This program focuses on the development of teaching strategies in home economics such as self-sufficiency and self reliance through active learning. Visits to markets and restaurants foster better understanding of multicultural food customs.

results.title: Dysphasic school children
results.creator_credit: Louise Janas and Victoria. Dept. of Education and Early Childhood Development
results.brief_description: Dysphasic children are those who have trouble expressing and understanding language, and are thus unable to take advantage of much classroom teaching. This program outlines the different teaching methods required to help with their speech difficulties.

results.title: Question of prejudice
results.brief_description: A study of the racist atitudes of some Australians toward migrant Australians, highligting the ‘wog’ syndrome. Investigtes the discrimination shown in the workforce towards groups such as the Lebanese, and its human effects such as the loss of self-esteem. Includes the views of Robert Cameron (White Australia Movement) and children.

results.title: Acoustic behaviour of the grey kangaroo
results.creator_credit: Ross Christopher and Australian National University
results.brief_description: Looks at the work done at the Acoustic Laboratory of the research School of Biological Sciences at the Australian National University on senses in kangaroos. Shows the environment of the kangaroo and how its hearing is used in cooperation with its eyes for scanning.

results.title: Drink-driving education
results.creator_credit: Greg Reading, Jan Sharp, Tom Chen, Peter Johnson, Peter Skolinick and New South Wales. Dept. of Education
results.brief_description: A compilation of “Drinking, driving, surviving”, “Saturday night again” and “The Thirsty season”. Covers physiological effects of alcohol; the social context and advertising.

results.title: Keeping wool in shape
results.brief_description: Examines Australian advances in wool science from new methods of washing and spinning raw wool to technologically advanced techniques for dyeing, shrinkproofing and printing wool textiles. Suitable for upper secondary level.
